verses.text: Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him.
verses.comment: Jacob encounters angels again, just as he did at Bethel (Gen. 28:12), signifying God’s ongoing protection and guidance. The visible presence of angels foreshadows the New Testament revelation of angels ministering to Christ (Matt. 4:11, Luke 22:43).

verses.text: When Jacob saw them, he said, 'This is God’s camp.' So he named that place Mahanaim.
verses.comment: ‘Mahanaim’ means ‘two camps.’ Jacob acknowledges both his own camp and God's camp of angels, showing the intertwined reality of the visible and spiritual realms. This subtle sacramental worldview implies God’s presence in ordinary places.

verses.text: Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom.
verses.comment: Jacob approaches reconciliation with humility, a foreshadowing of Christ's teachings on forgiveness and charity (Matt. 5:23–24; Matt. 18:21-22).

verses.text: He instructed them, 'Say to my lord Esau, “Your servant Jacob says: I have lived with Laban and stayed until now.”'
verses.comment: Jacob’s use of 'my lord' and 'your servant' expresses deep humility, echoing themes of submission and mediation.

verses.text: 'I have oxen, donkeys, flocks, male servants, and female servants. I am sending this to inform my lord, so that I may find favor in your sight.'
verses.comment: Jacob presents his prosperity as a gesture of good will. Such offerings resemble covenant gestures or 'peace offerings.'

verses.text: The messengers returned to Jacob, saying, 'We went to your brother Esau, and he is coming to meet you, and four hundred men are with him.'
verses.comment: Esau’s large company sounds ominous. Jacob is faced with his greatest fear, underscoring the need for faith and trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: Jacob was greatly afraid and distressed. He divided the people with him, and the flocks and herds and camels, into two camps.
verses.comment: Jacob acts with prudence, dividing his company in calculated hope that some may escape. His fear reveals human weakness before trials but sets the stage for reliance on God.

verses.text: He thought, 'If Esau comes to one camp and attacks it, the other camp will escape.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s contingency plan again demonstrates practical wisdom, yet underneath is anxiety—an opportunity for God’s transformative action.

verses.text: Then Jacob prayed, 'O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O LORD who told me, “Return to your country and to your relatives, and I will make you prosper,”'
verses.comment: Jacob appeals to God’s covenant promises, which anticipate the enduring faith handed down from Abraham to Isaac—mirroring an unbroken tradition ministered through generations (Heb. 11:9).

verses.text: 'I am not worthy of all the mercy and the faithfulness that you have shown to your servant. For with only my staff I crossed this Jordan, and now I have become two camps.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s confession expresses unworthiness and gratitude—a model for Christian humility, reminiscent of the prayer life taught in worship throughout history.

verses.text: 'Deliver me, I pray, from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I fear him, that he may come and attack me, the mothers with the children.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s prayer for deliverance echoes the psalms and anticipates Christian teachings about intercession and the protection of families.

verses.text: 'But you said, “I will surely make you prosper and make your offspring as the sand of the sea, which cannot be counted because of its multitude.”'
verses.comment: Jacob recalls God’s promise, paralleling prophetic assurances of blessing that find ultimate fulfillment in Christ and his spiritual descendants (Gal. 3:29).

verses.text: He spent the night there. From what he had with him, he selected a gift for his brother Esau.
verses.comment: Jacob prepares gifts as a peacemaking gesture—a practice preserved in traditions which respect offering as a visible sign of reconciliation.

verses.text: Two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
verses.comment: The richness of Jacob’s gift underscores overabundant giving, a motif of self-giving in the service of peace.

verses.text: Thirty camels with their young, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
verses.comment: Jacob provides gifts that are both practical and symbolic, reminiscent of offerings of first fruits mentioned elsewhere (Deut. 26:1-2).

verses.text: He gave them to his servants, every herd by itself, and said to his servants, 'Pass over before me, and put some distance between each herd.'
verses.comment: Deploying gifts in stages creates a generous impression, increasing hope for reconciliation—a practice reflected in the custom of preparing for holy encounters.

verses.text: He instructed the first, 'When Esau my brother meets you and asks, “Whose are you? Where are you going? Whose are these ahead of you?”'
verses.comment: The repeated question and response imply careful mediation, akin to forms of priestly intercession in later traditions.

verses.text: Then you shall say, “They belong to your servant Jacob. It is a gift sent to my lord Esau. And he himself is behind us.”
verses.comment: Jacob’s careful wording reveals wisdom in reconciling family division, echoing Christ’s call for peacemakers (Matt. 5:9).

verses.text: He also instructed the second and the third, and all who followed the herds: 'You shall say the same thing to Esau when you find him.'
verses.comment: Repetition reinforces sincerity and humility; the notion of persistent intercession is significant in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: 'Also say, “Your servant Jacob is behind us.”' For he thought, 'I will appease him with the gifts that go ahead of me, and afterward I will see his face; perhaps he will accept me.'
verses.comment: To 'see his face' recalls similar expressions about seeing God's face, often used in liturgical blessings and prayers.

verses.text: So the gifts passed ahead of him, but he stayed that night in the camp.
verses.comment: Jacob remains behind, quiet and vulnerable. This moment’s suspense presages his encounter with the divine.

verses.text: That night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven sons and crossed the ford of the Jabbok.
verses.comment: The Jabbok crossing marks Jacob’s threshold for transformative encounter, likened to moments of spiritual transition in sacred history.

verses.text: After he had sent them across the stream, he sent over all his possessions.
verses.comment: Jacob is left alone — a classic biblical motif for encounter with God (see Moses on Sinai, Elijah at Horeb).

verses.text: Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him until the break of day.
verses.comment: Here Jacob contends with a mysterious figure - later understood as a theophany, a visible manifestation of God. This prefigures Christ’s incarnation, in whom God is truly present and wrestles with humanity.

verses.text: When the man saw that he could not overpower him, he touched Jacob’s hip and dislocated it as they wrestled.
verses.comment: The injury signifies the spiritual transformation and the mark of blessing; weakness leads to deeper reliance on God.

verses.text: Then he said, 'Let me go, for it is daybreak.' But Jacob replied, 'I will not let you go unless you bless me.'
verses.comment: Jacob seeks a blessing, not a mere victory. Being persistent in prayer mirrors the teachings of Jesus on persevering prayer (Luke 18:1-8).

verses.text: The man asked him, 'What is your name?' He answered, 'Jacob.'
verses.comment: The renewal of name recalls the biblical importance of names—signifying mission, identity, and vocation. Similar to how Christ renames Simon Peter (John 1:42).

verses.text: Then he said, 'Your name shall no longer be Jacob, but Israel, for you have struggled with God and with humans and have prevailed.'
verses.comment: Jacob receives a new identity. The renaming by a divine figure resonates with Christ’s giving new life—and spiritual status—within his body, the Church. ‘Israel’ means ‘he who struggles with God.’

verses.text: Jacob asked, 'Please tell me your name.' But he replied, 'Why do you ask my name?' Then he blessed him there.
verses.comment: The mysterious refusal to reveal the name echoes God’s hiddenness and transcendence. The blessing grants Jacob a new standing.

verses.text: So Jacob named the place Peniel, saying, 'For I have seen God face to face, and yet my life was spared.'
verses.comment: Peniel means 'face of God.' Jacob’s experience marks a unique encounter with the divine—a moment of intimacy that points toward mankind’s hope to see God ‘face to face’ in the fullness of time (1 Cor. 13:12).

verses.text: The sun rose upon him as he passed Peniel, and he limped because of his hip.
verses.comment: Jacob’s limp is a reminder of his encounter—a mark of spiritual transformation, reminiscent of tradition’s view of suffering as redemptive.

verses.text: Therefore, to this day, the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the hip socket, because Jacob’s hip was touched near the socket.
verses.comment: This detail records a traditional food law rooted in God’s encounter with Israel. The sanctification of ordinary actions demonstrates how encounters with God can shape communal life.
